guide.title: #gentoo Structure Guide
guide.abstract: This guide is meant to outline the structure of the #gentoo IRC channel.

body.p: This document outlines the structure of #gentoo.

Currently #gentoo is an extremely large channel of users, numbering close to 1000 users. It is also the homefront of people trying out Gentoo for the first time. Because of this, it needs a more structured form to handle things.
The structure of #gentoo will be as follows:

ol.li: Tor Users: Level 10 - Currently because of the inability to successfully manage the actions of tor users, the entire domain is silenced. This access is for autovoice, which will let them speak.
Level 20 for developers. Developers will be able to OP themselves, but cannot handle general channel management such as AKICK and adding other users.
Level 30 for staff - This is for staff, or people that help manage day to day #gentoo tasks. They are allowed access to the AKICK function.
Level 40 for admins - This is for toplevel managment. Said persons will be able to do things such as alter the access list for adjusting permissions.

body.p: Here is a list of the capabilities of users based on their level:

ul.li: Only Gentoo Developers can be level 40 admins.
Only staffs and up can deal with .tor user applications. This is because they best understand how #gentoo operates, and who can cause problems.
Developers can obtain status in the channel by request to an admin.
Inactive users without a good reason will have their access downgraded or removed depending on the situation. Inactive is defined as 2 weeks.
Currently, bans are set for 2 weeks, after which they will be removed. If a user is banned 3 times, they are immediately put in the AKICK list.
Ban complaints should be sent to: ops@gentoo.org
Public discussion should be sent to the public access gentoo-ops mailing list or to #gentoo-ops.
AKICK is a serious ban. Only a full agreed vote of all active admins and staff (other than the staff member in question) can remove it!
